titleStmt.title: Letter from William F. Cody to R. F. Elwell, May 29 [1901]

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

notesStmt.note: Year 1901 determined by routes list: BBWW performed in Pittsburg, Pennsylvania, on 28-29 May 1901.

bibl.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
bibl.title: Letter from William F. Cody to R. F. Elwell

msIdentifier.repository: McCracken Research Library, Buffalo Bill Center of the West

div1.p: Glad to get your nice letter—From camp—Its strange to me—that people cant learn to allwaysalways set there camps in se cludedsecluded places out of the wind. This should be done— Speak to Mr Kelsey. allsoalso try and locate the camp where there is grass—I am surprised that active work was not commenced at once—Tell Mr Martin3 to let you keep the Pony for your use—Will be glad to see your sketches & letter in the Enterprise4. I havent haven't heard from Mrs Elwell5—if she got the money—Keep the Mexican saddle for your use DontDon't bother about going to TE6— to measure the land—till you are there some time. Do you think water can be taken out of the river by a head gate and put on the truck—

back.note: Note 1: Buffalo Bill's Wild West performed in Pittsburgh on 28 and 29 May 1901.
Note 4: Probably John Martin, who was then an agent for William F. Cody's business interests in the town that bore his name.
Note 5: The Cody Enterprise, a newspaper founded by William F. Cody in 1899, still the main local newspaper in the town of Cody, Wyoming.
Note 6: R.F. Elwell had married Mary Ellen Taylor (born c. 1875) in 1897.
Note 7: The TE Ranch, located on the South Fork of the Shoshone River, was a favorite retreat for Cody in the last two decades of his life.
